== Introduction ==
The target of this page is to collect Lenovo OEM PC information that could be a reference for the end-users.

To check if your laptop/desktop is certified, please search it in the below links.

https://ubuntu.com/certified/laptops?vendor=Lenovo
https://ubuntu.com/certified/desktops?vendor=Lenovo

=== Known generic issues ===
All issues related to the certified machines are tracked by <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/oem-priority|oem-priority project]]</nowiki>

==== The Intel MIPI Camera ====
* IPU6/IPU6EP stack was tested on some certified platforms
 It contains the characteristic below:
* The IPU6 kernel driver is out-of-tree, we are collaborating with Intel about the upstream and maintenance
* Camera performance: 720p at 30fps
* CPU performance is impacted by a daemon doing buffer copying for v4l2 loopback device.
* To install IPU6/IPU6EP stack maunally on certified platform which install 22.04 stock Ubuntu
** ThinkPad X1 Nano Gen 2 (8086:465d)
** ThinkPad X1 Yoga Gen 7 (8086:465d)
** ThinkPad X1 Carbon Gen 10 (8086:465d)
** ThinkPad X1 Yoga Gen 8 (8086:a75d)
** ThinkPad X1 Carbon Gen 11 (8086:a75d)
** ThinkPad X1 2-in-1 Gen 9 (8086:7d19)
** ThinkPad X1 Carbon Gen 12 (8086:7d19)

<pre>
$ sudo apt install ubuntu-oem-keyring
$ sudo add-apt-repository "deb http://lenovo.archive.canonical.com/ jammy sutton"
$ ubuntu-drivers list
...
libcamhal0
...
$ sudo apt install libcamhal0 \
 linux-generic-hwe-22.04 \
 linux-modules-ipu6-generic-hwe-22.04 \
 linux-modules-usbio-generic-hwe-22.04
$ sudo reboot
</pre>

** If you want install 24.04 stock Ubuntu on 22.04 certified platforms. Please find the correct libcamhal- package with 'ubuntu-drivers list', then use linux-generic-hwe-24.04 with below command.
<pre>
$ sudo apt install ubuntu-oem-keyring
$ sudo add-apt-repository "deb http://lenovo.archive.canonical.com/ noble sutton"

$ ubuntu-drivers list
libcamhal-ipu6epmtl   # it might be libcamhal-ipu7x

$ sudo apt install libcamhal-ipu6epmtl \ # please replace to libcamhal-ipu7x depends on the output above.
 linux-generic-hwe-24.04 \
 linux-modules-ipu6-generic-hwe-24.04 \
 linux-modules-ipu7-generic-hwe-24.04 \
 linux-modules-vision-generic-hwe-24.04 \
 linux-modules-usbio-generic-hwe-24.04
</pre>

* Manually installing the IPU6/IPU7 stack on a certified platform with Ubuntu 24.04
** ThinkPad X1 Carbon Gen 13 and ThinkPad X1 2-in-1 Gen 10 (8086:645d) (BIOS:N4BET63W for LunarLake)
<pre>
$ ubuntu-drivers list
 oem-sutton-dacia-meta
$ sudo apt install -y oem-sutton-dacia-meta ; sudo apt update
$ ubuntu-drivers list
 libcamhal-ipu7x
 oem-sutton-dacia-meta
$ sudo apt intall -y oem-sutton-dacia-meta libcamhal-ipu7x
$ sudo reboot
</pre>
  You can install meta and intel MIPI driver with 'Additional Drivers' in 'Software & Updates'
  <nowiki>[[File:dacia.png||width=660]]</nowiki>

** ThinkPad X1 Carbon Gen 13 and ThinkPad X1 2-in-1 Gen 10 (8086:7d19)(BIOS:N4MET25W for ArrowLake)
<pre>
$ ubuntu-drivers list
 oem-sutton-daisy-meta
$ sudo apt install -y oem-sutton-daisy-meta ; sudo apt update
$ ubuntu-drivers list
 libcamhal-ipu6epmtl
 oem-sutton-daisy-meta
$ sudo apt intall -y oem-sutton-daisy-meta libcamhal-ipu6epmtl
$ sudo reboot
</pre>
  You can install meta and intel MIPI driver with 'Additional Drivers' in 'Software & Updates'
  <nowiki>[[File:daisy.png||width=660]]</nowiki>

==== The Quectel Wireless WAN devices with fccunlock ====

First, check your device if it's supportd by lenovo-wwan-unlock, https://github.com/lenovo/lenovo-wwan-unlock

If your laptop is certified, for example, ThinkPad X1 2-in-1 Gen 10, you could use the comands below.
<pre>
$ ubuntu-driver list
 oem-sutton-dacia-meta
$ sudo apt install -y oem-sutton-dacia-meta ; sudo apt update
$ ubuntu-driver list
 oem-sutton-daisy-meta
 lenovo-wwan-unlock
$ sudo apt install -y oem-sutton-daisy-meta lenovo-wwan-unlock
</pre>
 You can install meta and fccunlock package with 'Additional Drivers' in 'Software & Updates'
 <nowiki>[[File:dacia.png||width=660]]</nowiki>

For uncertified platforms, you could use below tips to install fccunlock package.
<pre>
$ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:lenovo-oem/wwan
$ sudo apt update
$ ubuntu-drivers list
 lenovo-wwan-unlock
$ sudo apt install lenovo-wwan-unlock
</pre>

==== The MOH Fingerprint devices from FPC, ELAN and Goodix ====
* Some certified platforms might be affected
** ThinkPad E14 Gen 4
** ThinkPad E15 Gen 4
** ThinkPad E14 Gen 5
** ThinkPad E16 Gen 1
** ThinkBook 14 Gen 4
* If above platforms have below supported MOH fingerprint sensor list, you could check them from lsusb and install the driver.
** ELAN(04f3:0c46) - Bus 003 Device 002: ID 04f3:0c4b Elan Microelectronics Corp. ELAN:Fingerprint
** FPC(10a5:9800) - Bus 003 Device 002: ID 10a5:9800 FPC FPC Sensor Controller L:0001 FW:16.26.23.22
** Goodix(27c6:550a) - Bus 003 Device 002: ID 27c6:550a Shenzhen Goodix Technology Co.,Ltd. FingerPrint

* How to install fingerprint driver? ubuntu-driver could find the supported packages for your devices.
<pre>
   $ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:libfprint-tod1-group/ppa
   $ sudo apt update
   $ ubuntu-driver list
   libfprint-2-tod1-elan
   $ sudo apt install libfprint-2-tod1-elan
   or start 'Software & Updates', click 'Additional Drivers', and select 'ELAN' item and click 'Apply Changes'
   $ software-properties-gtk
</pre>

==== The color temperature can't be adjusted ====
* It's a general issue, we found this issue on some certified platforms like:
** ThinkPad T15p Gen 3
** ThinkPad X13 Yoga Gen 3
** ThinkPad X13 Gen 3
* 5.14.0-oem kernel is end of life, it is fixed by 5.15.0-41 or later one.
<pre>
    $ sudo apt update
    $ sudo apt install linux-generic-hwe-20.04
</pre>

== Limitations ==
==== Unattended upgrade makes nvidia driver unusable ====
* <nowiki>[[ https:--bugs.launchpad.net-ubuntu-+source-unattended-upgrades-+bug-2091604 | LP: #2091604 Dependencies conflicts for NVIDIA driver migrating from 515 to 535 ]]</nowiki>

 If the platforms are certified and preloaded with the 5.17 OEM kernel and NVIDIA 515 driver, you may encounter the issue mentioned above on the I+N platform. Please '''upgrade''' to the latest packages following the steps below.

<pre>
    $ sudo apt update
    $ sudo apt dist-upgrade
</pre>
